title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.15.34 | 20-12-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjanishalakaya
Chakshurun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhakti Vedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Ganadhara Shri Vasadi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya
Naram Jai Vanarottamam Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam
Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we will be discussing from the 34th verse of the 15th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam
Yes
Jaya Harad Bhuvobharam Tam Tanum Vijahav Ajah
Kantakam Kantakenewa Dwayam Chapi Shituhu Samam
The meaning of this verse is
The supreme unborn Lord Shri Krishna
Caused the members of the Yadu dynasty to relinquish their bodies
And thus he relinquished their bodies
To relieve the burden of the world
This action was like picking out a thorn with a thorn
Though both are the same to the controller
Now this verse is an explanation of
The difficult to understand actions of the Lord Shri Krishna
The difficult to understand actions of the Lord Shri Krishna
The difficult to understand actions of the Lord Shri Krishna
The difficult to understand actions of the Lord Shri Krishna
And his pure devotees
Many places it is said all the Lord's activities or the pure devotees activities in this world are completely transcendental
But these transcendental activities are not always easy to understand
Some of them are very difficult to understand
Especially the
Some of them are very difficult to understand
members of the Yadu dynasty how did they relinquish their bodies how do they give
up their bodies fighting with each other killing each other getting intoxicated
and when fighting with each other this is how can this be understood as a
transcendental activity of the pure devotees the Yadavas the members of the
Yadu dynasty the associates of Krishna how can we understand so that is
explained in this verse so let's hear Srila Prabhupada's purport which will
wonderfully very nicely explain this particular verse in the purport Srila
Prabhupada says Srila Vishwanacharya
Chakravarti Thakur who is one of the previous Acharyas he suggests that the
rishis like Shaunaka and others who are hearing Srimad Bhagavatam from Suta
Goswami at Naimisharanya were not happy to hear about the Yadus dying in the
madness of intoxication the sages of Naimisharanya they are devotees now
they're hearing about
other devotees and the Yadus as devotees are they really fighting in the madness
of intoxication and dying due to that fighting so that is not very pleasing to
hear for them so here Srila Vishwanacharya Chakravarti Thakur explains that to give
them relief from this mental agony Suta Goswami assured them that they will not
suffer the pain of intoxication.
thisourage of the Yadus dynasty to relinquish their bodies by which they
had to take away the burden of the world
so this is a very confidential understanding the Yadu dynasty members had appeared in
the satchar traveling in satchar going through the satchar editing These must be the people who had come for knowledges.
in this world in order to assist the Lord in his leela of reducing the burden of this world
which is overburdened by asuras by demons and to reduce that burden of the earth planet
the Lord came along with his associates the members of the yadu dynasty now after the Lord
had annihilated these demons the yadu dynasty itself remained in this material world and they
could not be annihilated by anyone
else and after their work was over after their role was completed of assisting the Lord in this
material world to reduce the burden of the world then they are no longer required here so for them
to return to their original position
in the spiritual world the Lord made this arrangement that they kill each
other simply to give up their material bodies that's all so Srila Prabhupada further explains
this point the Lord and his eternal associates appeared on earth to help the administrative
demigods in eradicating the burdens of the world and to remove the burden of the world from the
of the world. He therefore called for some of the confidential demigods to
appear in the Yadu family and serve him in his great mission. After the mission
was fulfilled the demigods by the will of the Lord relinquished their corporeal
bodies by fighting amongst themselves in the madness of intoxication. Their
material bodies anyway they have to give up after their work is over.
Everybody gives up but how they give up? In their case it is by the arrangement
of the Supreme Lord. It's not their choice.
It's not their Karma. It is the arrangement of the Supreme Lord. So it is
the will of the Lord.
the Lord. The demigods are accustomed to drinking the Somarasa beverage and
therefore the drinking of wine and intoxication are not unknown to them.
Sometimes they were put into trouble for indulging in intoxication. Once the sons
of Kuvaira fell in the wrath of Narada for being intoxicated but afterwards
they regained their original forms by the grace of the Lord Sri Krishna. This
is explained in the 10th canto of the Bhagavata. We are still in the first canto.
10th canto this is explained this pastime of the Lord and how the two demigods the
sons of Kuvaira were delivered by Krishna even though they were cursed by
Narada they were delivered by Krishna. Now Prabhupada explains one important
point here for us to understand.
For the Supreme Lord both the Asuras and the demigods are equal. Why? Both of them
are his part and parcels. All living beings in the entire creation are part
and parcel of the Lord.
mamaivamso jivaloke jivabhutasanatanah
mama amsa they are my part. In the fourth chapter Krishna also says
yena bhutanee aseshani drakshasi atmani ataumayee
in the 35th of the sixth chapter that every living being is my part and
parcel its mine belongs to me is in me Krishna says in the fourth chapter the
Bhagavad-gita. So nobody is
independent in their entire being.
The Bhagavad Gita asks the personality to be independent
of the lord nobody is separate from the lord means nobody is unrelated to the lord everybody
is related connected as lord's own so that some of them are asuras and others are devatas
does not mean that the asuras don't belong to krishna and the devatas alone belong to krishna
no both of them belong to krishna so for the supreme lord both are equal
same thing krishna says in bhagavad gita the ninth chapter
the difference is however between the demigods and the
demons or the devatas and asuras the demigods are obedient to the lord
whereas
the asuras are not obedient to the lord
therefore the example of picking out a thorn by another thorn is quite befitting
the example that is given here is explained also by shrina pravpa what is this example
one thorn which causes pinpricks on the leg of the lord is certainly disturbing to the lord
and the other thorn which takes out the disturbing elements
certainly gives service to the lord
to understand this it's very common thing in
in agricultural fields when somebody is walking barefoot and let us say
because they're walking barefoot
a thorn pricks the leg the bottom of the foot the sole of the foot then to remove that thorn
sometimes may not be possible just by pulling it out because it is gone little deep inside
so then the person to remove that thorn takes another thorn and
and uses that second thorn to actually clear the skin in the area where the thorn is pricked
and thereby making it easy to pull out the thorn with the second thorn the first thorn
so this may not be
um
very
much an experience of the city people who never have to walk barefoot
who never have experience of a thorn pricking their leg
but this is the most appropriate example in this instance
so Prabhupada explains
although every living being is a part of the city
as long as they owned some of theين parts and parcel of the Lord
still one who is a pin prick to the Lord is called an hasura
who is disobedient and unnecessarily gives trouble to others
and one who is a voluntary servitor of the Lord is called a devata or demigod
both are parts and parcels of the lord both belong to the lord
but still one is called an asura another one is called the devata
In the material world, the devatas and asuras are always contending.
There is competition between them.
And the devatas are always saved from the hands of the asuras by the Lord.
Both of them are under the control of the Lord.
Both the devatas and asuras, both.
The world is full of two kinds of living beings.
Krishna explains this in the 16th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita.
So, there are two kinds of created beings, the devatas and asuras.
The Lord's mission is always to protect the devatas and destroy the asuras.
Whenever there is such a need in the world and to do good to both of them.
The Lord does.
Good to both of them.
Because whether he kills the asuras or protects the devatas, both are delivered by the Lord.
The contact with the Lord is assured, guaranteed liberation.
For whoever comes in contact, whichever way.
So, Lord does good to both.
He is not partial to the devatas.
So, I will stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Krishna.
